body_text.text: T he PetFAST reporting system (the Pet Food Adverse Event System of Tracking) was launched in February 2012. A small number of cases since then reveal that suspicions remain about pet treats associated with acquired Fanconi-like syndrome in small dogs.
PetFAST was conceived after a number of product recalls in 2008 and 2009, including a number of cases around Australia associated with Kramar chicken jerky dog treats.
"We started seeing a number of cases of acquired Fanconi-like syndrome in small dogs, and the one common factor seemed to be these treats, " said AVA member, Linda Fleeman.
"But we had no way of finding out how widespread the problem might be, or to figure out if there was a significant threat to dogs in Australia.

"After the AVA issued an alert to members, the media picked up the story and the treats were recalled from the market, but we haven't ever been able to discover a definite cause for the problem, " said Linda.
A small number of acquired Fanconi-like syndrome cases continue to emerge in Australia despite the fact that Kramar treats were withdrawn more than three years ago.
"We really don't know what's currently happening in these cases. Some seem to be associated with other dog treats, while a number seem to be linked to pigs' ears, " said Linda.
The question marks around what might be causing these mysterious illnesses reinforce the need for the national PetFAST reporting system in Linda's view.

"It's really crucial that vets report any cases that they suspect are associated with pet food, pet meat or pet treats. You can do it online in about 15 minutes, and it will help us identify any patterns that may be emerging.

"There are no government authorities to monitor adverse events with pet food, so PetFAST fills a critical gap. I encourage every vet to get to know PetFAST, and to log all cases of health problems they suspect are associated with pet food, " said Linda.

PetFAST is also designed to track incidents of thiamine deficiency resulting from sulphite preservatives. Reports are monitored by both the AVA and the Pet Food Industry Association of Australia, and a joint committee will be convened if patterns are emerging that may require action.

Visit www.ava.com.au/petfast to report a case, get more information or download a vet checklist on what to do if you suspect a pet food-associated adverse event. Cats are only doing what comes naturally when they urine mark, but it can be seriously inconvenient for the pet's family. So, what can be done? First we need to understand why cats urine mark.

When faced with a cat that is urinating around the house, it is essential to accurately distinguish between spraying and toileting. A cat performing toileting behaviour and not urine spraying is showing litter tray avoidance. This cat may be unhappy with its current litter tray or toileting arrangements. Whilst this may be a cause of anxiety, the litter tray situation should be a priority to question. Urine marking, characterised by the deposition of small amounts of urine on vertical surfaces, is one of the most common feline behaviour problems 1 . There are two types: sexual and reactional (anxiety-related). Sexual marking is associated with sexual excitement in male cats or the onset of oestrus in female cats. Anxiety-related marking is associated with a stressful event, a change in the cat's environment or an ongoing stressful situation, such as felines sharing space in multi-cat households 2 .

After ruling out any possible medical causes, strategies to treat urine marking in multi-cat households include: feeding in separate rooms, providing multiple resources (food and water bowls, litter boxes) and providing enough climbing, hiding and resting areas for all the cats. Other strategies include behavioural modifications to remove any specific triggers, and the use of feline facial pheromone, as provided by Feliway 3 .

Feliway is a synthetic copy of the F3 fraction of the facial pheromone that's scientifically proven to reassure and comfort cats. By mimicking the cat's natural pheromones, it creates a state of familiarity and security in the cat's local environment.

Feliway is available in both a diffuser and a spray. To reduce urine marking with Feliway, first the urine marked areas need to be cleaned with an enzymatic cleaner (eg. Trigene wipes), and allowed to dry naturally. A Feliway diffuser should then be plugged into the room where the marking has taken place and switched on for at least 4 weeks (if the cat marks several rooms, it may be necessary to use the spray as well). As additional support to the diffuser, Feliway spray can also be used. After cleaning, Feliway spray should be applied daily to both the urine marked sites and prominent objects. Treatment should be continued for at least one month and stopped when the cat marks the area with its own facial pheromone.

The effects of Feliway have been demonstrated in more than 16 published papers and over a decade of use. For example, in one trial 2 , 57 multi-cat households with urine spraying behaviour issues, owners applied Feliway Spray twice daily to urine marked spots and prominent objects in the home. At the end of the trial, it was shown that: Feliway reduced the total number of urine marks per week throughout the trial, with a significant reduction in the first week. Complete elimination of urine marking occurred in 33% of the participating households after four weeks 2 . So what are the main changes members will notice to Vet Ed?
body_text.section: Evaluation of a feline facial pheromone analogue to control urine spraying

body_text.text: There are a few visual things you'll notice immediately. There's now a 'Vet Ed' tab accessible from every page of the AVA website and when you click on this you'll be taken to our new brightlycoloured and clearly marked Vet Ed pages.
body_text.section: Evaluation of a feline facial pheromone analogue to control urine spraying

body_text.text: Anything to do with continuing professional development is now in one place on the website. What we have is a 'one-stop-shop' for all your continuing professional development needs. This includes the Vet Ed calendar, which lists all of the upcoming events, the Info hub, which includes information about continuing professional development for members in each stage of their careers as well as information on courses and activities run by the AVA, universities and other service providers, and the Vet Ed library, a fully searchable library of quality AVA publications, but more about that in a minute.
body_text.section: Evaluation of a feline facial pheromone analogue to control urine spraying

body_text.text: Truth be told, it was quite difficult to find all the information you needed before. There was no one place to search for information, to manage your education points -things were quite scattered and I think this is a big improvement. You can even access the section directly using www.veted.com.au. Now what we're giving you is a place where all the information you need is in one section on the website. You can manage all your development needs without clicking away from the Vet Ed pages. And don't forget if you can't find something you're looking for, just type it into the search box in the right hand corner of the site and you're sure to find the information you're after.
body_text.section: How is it different to what was offered before?

body_text.text: What it really means is that you can plan the professional development you want depending on the stage your career is at. And not only can you have a plan and set your own goals for what education you want to do you can actually get Vet Ed points for doing that planning. It's a double bonus.
body_text.section: What does this mean for managing education?

body_text.text: But it's more than that. We identified a need to simplify the way members access all the elements of their continuing professional development and then we've gone about producing it.
body_text.section: What does this mean for managing education?

body_text.text: However, I want to stress that this is still a work in progress and I encourage all members to have a play with the site and all of its functions and then to let me know the things they like and appreciate about it and, of course, the things they feel could be enhanced and improved. There is a dedicated thread on the discussion forums for feedback on the Vet Ed pages, visit www.ava.com.au/forum/vet-ed-library-feedback to make a comment.
body_text.section: What does this mean for managing education?

body_text.text: There are still a few things we are working on, but we aim to have these up and running in the near future.
body_text.section: What does this mean for managing education?

body_text.text: The Vet Ed library is new and it's the bit I'm most excited about. Based on the NZVA Sciquest, it brings together all the publications of the AVA into the one spot. It means that you can go there and search for clinical information from our special interest groups and conference proceedings. Anything you need to know about anything veterinary, you type it in you'll find all the documents relating to that topic.
body_text.section: one of the big changes is the new Vet Ed library. How does it work?

body_text.text: While there are some restrictions, each special interest group has made most information available to all members. It's a fantastic resource and it's a real member benefit for being a part of the AVA.
body_text.section: one of the big changes is the new Vet Ed library. How does it work?

body_text.text: is it true you can make comments on articles directly?
body_text.section: one of the big changes is the new Vet Ed library. How does it work?

body_text.text: We're really keen to promote discussion among members about things that are important to them, to ask for advice or even to make a comment about something they don't agree with. And if you have found an article that you feel warrants debate or you need further information, we've provided a link to the discussion forums in the left hand menu.
body_text.section: one of the big changes is the new Vet Ed library. How does it work?

body_text.text: Vet Ed value is where you can go and get extra value for your membership. It's where we list all the member discounts on a range of development opportunities. We even list some free activities which can earn you points.

The Vet Ed site is still undergoing some development. It's a bit of an organic beast. There is something we still need from members and that's more feedback. I really want people to take a look at the site and send me their thoughts about where we could make changes (visit www.ava.com.au/forum/vet-ed-library-feedback to make a comment or suggestion). This is a major member benefit and we really want our members to drive this and tell us what they want to see there.

This site brings all of our continuing professional development information and resources together. We can look and search for all of our documents in the one place, and the hope for the longer term is to bring all of the AVA's documents to this place and members will be able to capture a greater search. In the future we want to have power points, webinars and other mixed media type information on there as well.

Comment on this article at www.ava.com.au/12073 Government officials, livestock leaders, scientists and peak industry stakeholders met in Sydney in August to review the nation's preparedness and response capacity for foot-and-mouth disease (FMD).

Stakeholders at the forum discussed the potential use of vaccination against FMD, strengthening Australia's emergency response capacities, and the use of scanning and strategic intelligence to provide early warning of disease threats.

Australia's Chief Veterinary Officer, Mark Schipp, said the collaborative work being undertaken to achieve long-term enhancement of Australia's preparedness and capacity to respond to an FMD outbreak was a positive move towards protecting the Australian economy from an outbreak of FMD.

"The FMD forum, hosted by the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, marks the first time we have seen a truly national approach to addressing the threat of FMD. Constant vigilance and awareness about the risks, and determination to protect the livestock industry is the only way to ensure we do not suffer dire economic consequences. " "That's why many sessions of the forum were devoted to issues of shared responsibility, and how the Australian Government, industries, states and territories and other stakeholders can collaborate to ensure optimal national FMD preparedness, " said Dr Schipp.

"This included discussion of ways to facilitate the engagement of private vets in emergency animal disease responses. Work has already commenced on this aspect of Australia's response capability with consideration being given to remuneration, insurance issues, private practice business continuity and contract arrangements. Australia's previous experience with emergency use of private practitioners is informing this work.

"In addition, the agreement by all stakeholders, especially around swiftly implementing a vaccination campaign if needed, will ensure Australia is better prepared for the threat of FMD, " said Dr Schipp.

Forum attendees also agreed to support improved FMD preparedness as a continuing national biosecurity and animal health priority, and noted the significant progress made in FMD preparedness by the collaborative efforts of all relevant governments and industry against the recommendations of the Matthews Review.

"Support for the conduct of a national livestock standstill simulation exercise to test current response arrangements will also ensure these are effective at that critical time when an FMD outbreak is first discovered, " said Dr Schipp.
Attendees also noted the national definitions for swill and swill-feeding being developed and the development of a compliance program to enforce swill feeding legislation.
"Vets can play an important role in raising awareness about swill feeding, " said Dr Schipp.
"Vets in contact with pig farmers or pig keepers (including pet pigs) can emphasise key messages relating to the nationally legislated bans on swill feeding of pigs.

"Swill feeding has been identified as the highest risk pathway for FMD to enter and establish in Australia's livestock population. High risk materials that constitute swill generally include all forms of meat and certain forms of dairy products and by-products. "
Comment on this article at www.ava.com.au/12075
body_text.section: Office of the Chief Veterinary Officer

body_text.text: Australian Veterinary Journal Volume 90, No 10, October 2012 NEWS N8 NEWS L ast month I provided a response to the question of how animal welfare fits within the AVA as an organisation. One of the phrases I used that I think summarises our role as veterinarians is to assist where feasible for animals to have "a good life and a good death".
In this column I want to explore 'a good death' and our role in ending animal lives.

Every living organism from viruses to humans dies, either by natural causes or human intervention. For the purposes of this column I include all deaths other than those by human intervention, as natural, so includes disease, predation, traumatic accidents, environmental and nutritional mortalities, toxicoses and aged organ failure.

Yet all living things possess an innateness to live. Even the simple mosquito takes evasive flight when confronted with a threatening hand, and I recall watching an amazing video of a motile bacteria being chased around a capillary by a leucocyte (though I think the bacteria's apparent evasive movement was random). We do not know the level of complexity or simplicity that each species possesses about living and dying, but our very safe society is almost obsessive about death and cannot help drifting to some degree of anthropomorphism. Just watching the efforts of protective mothers of many species shows us that there is something deeper than just innate threat aversion to themselves, but I do not suggest any species other than humans plan their retirement, or contemplate the type of death they will one day endure.
So where am I taking this?

Since I graduated in 1979, I have frequently wondered about the number of times I have actually performed lifesaving interventions for animals, not just hastened recovery, improved a quality of life or prevented illness, but actually prevented its imminent death. And then I compare this to the number of life-ending interventions I have conducted. Most of these have been via lethal intravenous injection, and most of us would argue that this technique is the 'gold standard' in terms of a good death, when one considers the needs of both the animal and the client.

In fact, since I have been in the same mixed rural practice for over thirty years with a reasonably stable client pool, it has been interesting to see the transition of many farmers previously seeing it as their duty to 'put down' their aged and ailing working dogs by shooting them, to now more commonly having them euthanased by lethal injection, despite the fact that the instant death by gunshot to the head is probably an equally good death for the dog, but more traumatic for the owner.

As a society we develop acceptable practices for killing different species and even different subclasses within species. For example a veterinarian would not use a gun to euthanase a pet dog whereas wild dog carnage of grazing animals is on the rise, and control techniques necessitate use of poisonous baits and shooting to reduce the killing of lambs and calves.

For euthanasia of horses I have mostly utilised lethal injection although there have been times and circumstances where this was inappropriate. For cattle and sheep on farm it is rare to use lethal injection since the carcase is rendered poisonous and unsuitable for utilisation as dog food, so a gunshot is more common.

Our society has very prescriptive techniques accepted for the slaughter of livestock for consumption as food, and last year the Four Corners expose of some of the livestock slaughter practises in Indonesia showed us how different cultures have evolved at different rates to different standards.

So we have a raft of different techniques to intervene to end animals' lives. As everyone who has an animal under their care knows, making the decision is often much more difficult. Many companion animals are able to be kept alive far longer than when I graduated due to advanced techniques in veterinary medicine, making decisions for owners more complex. Where once we might utter the words, "sorry but I'm afraid nothing can be done" we now suggest many more things can be done for a price.

Some clients feel unable to make such a momentous decision and insist on taking their pet home for a natural death. I have spoken to many veterinarians who feel a real conflict when this happens as in their opinion the animal should at least get the 'gold standard' death even if treatment is deemed unaffordable. Then there is the controversial government intervention to declare death for some dogs unworthy of existence by virtue of their appearance as dangerous, and the AVA has completed a great deal of work on this issue, but I will not attempt to include it here.

Domestic livestock are bred for the specific purpose of providing food, so for a rural mixed practitioner, all such animals that are saved by veterinary intervention are intended for slaughter before they reach aged degradation, although some will die a 'natural death' in the paddock. Many natural deaths are a combination of events. For example a cow becomes recumbent and unable to eat or drink, followed by scavengers making a start prior to death.

Few of these 'natural deaths' would be considered 'good' in terms of duration, pain and suffering or fear when compared with those by human interventions, including some techniques that our society finds unacceptable. It raises the question as to what extent can we and should we manage surveillance of these animals to intervene to save or destroy them.

Continued on page N10 www.atopica.com the simple joy of comfort Vets know that atopic dermatitis is a long-term challenge, and so do pet owners. When asked, owners of atopic dogs said they visited the vet 15 times to fi nd a solution 1 and tried at least 5 different treatments 2 . But that's before their pets were prescribed Atopica.

Atopica signifi cantly relieves pruritus and reduces skin lesions 3,4 , so dogs are happier. And pet owners love it too -94% would recommend Atopica to a friend 2 . So spread the joy and prescribe Atopica with confi dence.

To fi nd out more about how simple it can be to use Atopica, contact your Novartis Sales Representative. Clearly the capacity to shepherd livestock varies markedly between species, scale and environment. What might be expected of an intensive piggery, feedlot or dairy herd could not possibly be emulated in extensive grazing systems, and in the latter there are many natural deaths.

This brings me to the Sir David Attenborough documentaries that frequently explored death in the wild animal world. He could move us with the plight of the desperately starving antelope in a drought, and then a week later focus on the plight of the starving lions because of too few prey animals. Of particular fascination was the frenzied and desperate panic of the prey herd to evade the attacking lions, but then the amazing calm that seemed to ensue immediately after the target had been taken, the surviving herd even watching on from what seemed not much distance as the predators began consuming their victim.
While humans are responsible for managing the health, welfare and lives of animals that we care for and own, we

should not lose sight of the fact that the majority of living creatures on the planet will still endure a 'natural death' . Which raises the question, are we as a society at risk of becoming overly prescriptive about when and how animals should die? Either way, as a profession involved mostly with improving animal health and welfare, veterinarians are well placed to perform and advise on 'a good death' .
Comment on this article at www.ava.com.au/12074
A research program at the Melbourne Veterinary School has been chosen as one of the top ten best research projects of 2012 by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC).
The NHMRC has chosen Professor Marshall Lightowlers' research into a vaccine to prevent neurocyticercosis from among the thousands supported by the NHMRC in Australia.

Professor Lightowlers and his team's most recent contributions are vaccines for neurocysticercosis and hydatid, the diseases that occur when humans are infected with the larval stages of these tapeworm parasites. These infections affect around 50 million people worldwide and neurocysticercosis kills nearly 50,000 people worldwide annually. Professor Lightowlers opted to target the livestock rather than the people who are affected, as this is a much less expensive option than developing a human treatment.

Initially his team extracted a gene from the parasite that encodes a specific protein, and then produced that protein for use in making the vaccine. The team then went on to conduct international field trials in many countries including northern Cameroon. In the NHMRC booklet that features the top ten projects, Professor Lightowlers notes that their results were quite spectacular:

"When we examined our vaccinated pigs at the age when they are normally slaughtered and eaten, they didn't have a single parasite in them. We had achieved complete elimination of the transmission of the disease, " he said.
Other trials have all shown more than 99% protection.
A vaccine based on their technology to protect livestock from hydatid disease, is close to commercial production.
In another quote from the NHMRC brochure, Professor Lightowlers also said:

"I see myself as extraordinarily fortunate for two reasons. Not only do I perform scientific research for a living, which allows me to do something new and exciting more or less every day, but I can also see the products of my research going towards something that is genuinely going to improve human health. "
The booklet is available at www.nhmrc.gov.au/guidelines/publications/r52.
Editor in Chief A recent survey* revealed that >93% of companion animal vets rank safety of an induction drug as highly important.
The same survey showed that more vets choose Alfaxan® as their primary anaesthetic induction drug than all other anaesthetic drugs combined.
Alfaxan® helps make the complex process of anaesthesia consistently safer.
Jurox knows that using an anaesthetic drug correctly is vital to making anaesthesia safe. Ask for a training session in your practice today.

Anaesthesia is a complex process. helps make it safer. The awards have been created to recognise innovative researchers and veterinary scientists from around the world who have carried out research that has helped to improve the health and wellbeing of dogs.
body_text.section: Consistent induction Minimal systemic effects Rapid reliable recovery *Jurox Survey into anaesthetic use by Australian Companion Animal Practitioners 2011

body_text.text: There are three awards, two of which are open to Australian veterinarians. Both of these provide a large funding program to the recipient, which rewards them for their dedication and innovation in the field of canine health and welfare. The awards are:
body_text.section: Consistent induction Minimal systemic effects Rapid reliable recovery *Jurox Survey into anaesthetic use by Australian Companion Animal Practitioners 2011

body_text.text: • The Lifetime Achievement Award, which is for £10,000 to be presented to someone who has made a significant impact on the world stage of canine health.
body_text.section: Consistent induction Minimal systemic effects Rapid reliable recovery *Jurox Survey into anaesthetic use by Australian Companion Animal Practitioners 2011

body_text.text: • The International Prize in Canine Health Award, which is for £40,000 to be presented to someone who is currently involved in world class innovation, but with much still to contribute.
body_text.section: Consistent induction Minimal systemic effects Rapid reliable recovery *Jurox Survey into anaesthetic use by Australian Companion Animal Practitioners 2011

body_text.text: The awards will be judged by representatives from the veterinary profession and the world of scientific research, including experts in the nominees' selected fields. Alan Kelley, Dean Emeritus of The University of Pennsylvania School of Veterinary Medicine, will chair the committee selecting the international prize winner.
body_text.section: Consistent induction Minimal systemic effects Rapid reliable recovery *Jurox Survey into anaesthetic use by Australian Companion Animal Practitioners 2011

body_text.text: Rosemary Smart, Kennel Club Chief Executive, said: "We are extremely pleased to be working with Vernon and Shirley in this exciting awards scheme, which will reward and support those people whose work is making a difference to dogs' lives. "
body_text.section: Consistent induction Minimal systemic effects Rapid reliable recovery *Jurox Survey into anaesthetic use by Australian Companion Animal Practitioners 2011

body_text.text: Mike Townsend, Chairman of the Kennel Club Charitable Trust, said: "We encourage those whose work is making a difference to the future health of dogs to take the opportunity to enter these prestigious awards. "

body_text.text: The superannuation guarantee is the compulsory system of superannuation that must be paid to all employees by their employers.

Under the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 an employer is required to contribute to an employee's superannuation fund if they earn $450 or more (before tax) in a calendar month. The guarantee applies to all employees whether full-time, part-time, casual or seasonal. The superannuation guarantee determines the minimum superannuation entitlements paid to an employee which is currently set at 9% of the employee's ordinary time earnings (OTE).

In the 2010 Federal Budget, it was announced that there will be changes to the superannuation guarantee from 1 July 2013 until 1 July 2019. These changes were announced in light of an ageing population, to recognise possible future constraints on the retirement income of older Australians and to provide an incentive for them to remain in the workforce for longer. The changes to the superannuation guarantee include the abolition of the age limit for superannuation contributions, which means from 1 July 2013 employers will be required to contribute to the superannuation funds of all employees, regardless of their age.

Further changes to the superannuation guarantee will include an employers' superannuation contributions increase from the current rate of 9% to 12% by 1 July 2019. The increase will be phased-in over minimum increment contributions as shown in the table below:
Minimum employer contribution to superannuation 1 July 2013 9.25% 1 July 2014 9.5% 1 July 2015 10% 1 July 2016 10.5% 1 July 2017 11% 1 July 2018 11.5%

These changes do not affect the current superannuation rights and obligations under both the Animal Care and Veterinary Services Award 2010. The rights and obligations described under these awards supplement those in the superannuation legislation.
For more information on changes to superannuation or for any other employment related enquiries contact the AVA HR Advisory Service on 1300 788 977 or at hrhotline@ava.com.au.

A new National Farm Biosecurity Reference Manual for Grazing Livestock Production has been produced by Animal Health Australia (AHA) for use by producers. Livestock industries covered by this latest manual include all grazing species such as sheep, cattle, alpaca and goats. The manual clearly describes voluntary on-farm biosecurity measures which are simple and inexpensive to implement and help protect animals from infectious diseases. These actions have been developed through a science-based approach to reducing disease spread through identifying and managing the risks. "People involved at all levels of grazing livestock production, including veterinarians who support owners, managers and handlers of livestock, can take practical and cost effective steps to help protect Australian livestock from the introduction and spread of infectious diseases, " said Duncan Rowland, Executive Manager of Biosecurity Services at AHA. The manual is a reference document that has been designed for use by producers that manage multi-enterprise farms. It provides descriptions of recommended practices that fall under seven key areas of biosecurity principles. These include:

• Livestock -manage the introduction and movement of animals in a way that minimises the risk of introducing or spreading infectious diseases. • People, equipment and vehicles -ensure these are controlled to minimise the potential for contamination of the property. • Feed and water -ensure the quality of stock feed and water is fit for their purpose. • Pests and weeds -minimise the potential for wildlife and domestic or feral animals to introduce diseases to livestock. • Animal health management -prevent and control animal diseases on-farm by regularly monitoring livestock health. When you have to administer veterinary procedures or deliver pain relief, a reliable and highly predictable response will make your job easier.

Proudly introducing to Australia the latest additions to our product family… products you can trust We have had several letters, published below, in response to the Board resolutions on ineffective therapies, as outlined in our President's column in August, 1 and there seems to be some confusion about the purpose of these resolutions. The resolutions relate specifically to whether AVA member resources should be used to promote any therapies that have been shown to be ineffective. You can find the full wording at www.ava.com. au/12057.

It was the Board's decision that, specifically, homeopathy and homotoxicology have been afforded fair and sufficient evaluation and "are not compatible with current understanding of physiology and pathophysiology and have been demonstrated to be ineffective by the current accumulated body of knowledge. "

On that basis they cannot be promoted using AVA resources. The Board also note that member resources can be used for discussion of scientific evidence as long as the pros and cons are included equally, so my reading of this is that any balanced discussion of evidence would be, and indeed should be, the subject of continuing professional development.

The Board resolutions do not affect the peer review process, and all articles submitted to the Australian Veterinary Journal (AVJ) are subject to scientific review. I think that there is a huge need for more well-designed randomised trials in all aspects of veterinary medicine. However, experimental design has to be bomb proof, not least because articles would be gleefully taken apart by epidemiologists should we choose to accept poorly designed papers without stringent peer review.

I have to say that we would be unlikely to publish studies on any areas that are biologically implausible, and this is not just in areas of alternative medicine, but is a relatively common cause for us rejecting case reports in other disciplines.
A recent example is a case report that described unusual clinical signs in a horse at the same time as isolation of an unusual virus

Editor's note: Promotion is key 1 This is a retrograde step that will adversely affect many veterinary members who use these treatments. I hope that this exclusion will not extend to include acupuncture, chiropractic and other treatments that are not considered to be main stream.

The demand for alternative therapies by clients is increasing. I feel it is important that the veterinary profession should encourage its members to study these treatments instead of excluding them from professional development activities. Otherwise, there will be an insufficient number of properly trained veterinarians to service the demand and clients will have no option except seeking treatment from non-veterinary qualified practitioners. This is not unlike the situation that developed in recent years whereby horse owners had to resort to using non-veterinary qualified horse dentists since this service was not being adequately provided by members of the veterinary profession.
Members who want more information can visit www.facultyofhomeopathy.org/research/ and make up their own mind about the effectiveness of homeopathy.

Past President Australian Holistic Veterinarians re: ineffective therapies that generally was not associated with those signs. The authors concluded that it was a novel case of the virus causing that condition -the reviewers disagreed, and found that the disparate findings were coincidental, and so the paper was rejected.

Please note that while the AVJ is a good place for discussion, when there is a large volume of correspondence, it is impossible to include all letters. If you have further comments on this issue, I suggest that you contact your division or special interest group policy councillor.
Editor in Chief It is true to say that disagreement over what constitutes an ineffective therapy currently exists between the IVA and the AVA Board of Directors.

Most complementary and alternative therapies employed by veterinarians, including homeopathy and homotoxicology, are sound evidence-based scientific practices that an increasing number of people in Australia are successfully using for their own health and seeking for their pets.
Furthermore, an increasing number of Australian veterinarians are successfully employing homeopathic medicines in their veterinary practices.

In changing times, where the public is asking for more from veterinarians, it is counterproductive to reduce the services we can provide to AVA members by restricting access to continuing professional development that seeks to address this demand.

The AVA Professional Code of Conduct encourages us to foster and endeavour to strengthen relationships with our professional colleagues, utilising their skills where appropriate and maintaining and continuing to enhance professional knowledge and skills. IVA believes that veterinarians should have access to education in complementary and alternative veterinary medicine so that they can adequately respond to public enquiries and requests to provide these treatments for animals.
The promotion of ineffective therapies resolution will hamper continuing professional development within the AVA.

President Integrative Veterinarians Australia response to the release of the promotion of ineffective therapies resolution N22 NEWS I n a letter published in this journal in June 2012 1 , Dr Pearson informed readers that the name of a special interest group of the AVA -Australian Holistic Veterinarians -had been changed to Integrative Veterinarians Australia. Dr Pearson describes integrative (or integrated) medicine as "a practice that combines both conventional and complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) treatments for which there is evidence for safety and effectiveness. " That ambiguous sentence is clarified later in the letter as "…the integration of evidence-based complementary medicine into veterinary, research and education. "

The phrase "evidence-based complementary medicine" is an oxymoron. Complementary medicine is treatment for which evidence of safety and efficacy is lacking. When sufficient valid data for the efficacy of a treatment are examined and found to validate a claim for efficacy, then that treatment is described as evidence-based. If not so found, then the treatment is abandoned or is called by many names including complementary, alternative, quackery or worse.

Only when the data for efficacy of, for example, blood letting and 'firing' (cautery) of the lower limbs of horses were examined and found wanting, were these practices abandoned. Similarly, when data for efficacy of digitalis, St John's wort, and for artemisinin derivatives 2 were examined and validated, the use of each ceased as a complementary medicine because each was then an evidence-based conventional medicine.

When Singh and Ernst examined the evidence for and against the efficacy of various forms of alternative medicine, four in particular: acupuncture, homoeopathy, chiropractic therapy and herbal medicine, they reported that that some herbal medicines, alone among the alternative treatments they investigated, compared well against conventional options for the same condition. They concluded "therefore, alternative medicine, by definition, seems to consist of treatments that are untested, or unproven, or unsafe, or placebos, or only marginally beneficial. Yet, alternative therapists continue to wear the name 'alternative' as a badge of honour, using it to give their substandard treatments an undeserved level of dignity. " 3 It seems that this badge now bears the word 'integrative' .

It is at best misleading to claim that treatments for which scientifically acceptable evidence of their efficacy has not been adduced should be considered equal to conventional treatments. Attempts by their adherents to integrate alternative and conventional treatments should be resisted; rather, the treatments are distinct and should continue to be differentiated.
Canterbury, Victoria

Submission of photographs for publication will be held to imply that permission for publication has been obtained from the photographer and from the subject(s) of the image.AVJ.PI.Feb12 TRADEMARKS AVA and the AVA logo are registered trademarks of the Australian Veterinary Association Limited.In practice, DAFF requires an accredited veterinarian to travel on a voyage to South-East Asia if it is a maiden voyage, or following a reportable mortality event in a previous voyage by the same vessel, or from the same exporter.DAFF is currently reviewing the Australian Standards for the Export of Livestock, standard 5 of which covers on-board management of livestock. This provides an opportunity for DAFF to review the present policy on the role of veterinarians on-board livestock vessels.For livestock export, the prescribing veterinarian will provide instructions and support to the stockman, much in the way that they do for pastoral properties under their care. Veterinary directions and the authority to prescribe are provided by state and territory legislation and the Commonwealth may refer any matters for investigation where appropriate. In relation to the 2011 Brunei voyage, drugs administration during the voyage was not referred for investigation as there was no evidence that the prescribing veterinarian failed to comply with state legislative requirements. In addition, the stockman treated the animals in accordance with the Stockman's Handbook: Transport of Cattle by Sea, although DAFF's investigation report does acknowledge that record keeping could have been improved.For all live export consignments, the animals are examined by a DAFF Biosecurity (formerly AQIS) accredited veterinarian shortly prior to export and are found to be fit and healthy. The veterinarian has the power to remove any animals from the export chain and investigate any mortalities. In addition, the animals are inspected on arrival by the veterinary services of our trading partners. Any suspected disease event is communicated and investigated.

By way of comment on the recent letter, 1 Recommendation 8 of the AVA submission to the Farmer Independent Review into Australia's Livestock Export Trade read:A suitably qualified and experienced veterinarian should be on all voyages to ensure the highest standards of animal health and welfare can be put into place. Such responsibilities should not be transferred to non-veterinarians of varying training and capabilities.This recommendation was not accepted in the report of the Farmer Review.

It is interesting that an organisation with the stated aim of "giving the public, veterinarians and the government an independent, balanced and objective scientific view of animal welfare and regulation of the [live export] industry" 1 sallies forth under the independent, balanced and objective name of Vets Against Live Export.
